title: Space Policy
description: The increasing commercialization and militarization of space has led to a new geopolitical reality beyond Earthâ€™s atmosphere. Civil space agencies like the National Aeronautics and Science Administration (NASA) and the European Space Agency (ESA) have historically served as instrumental hubs for space exploration and innovation. At the same time, U.S.-based commercial company SpaceX has transformed the launch industry and contributed to the congestion of Low Earth Orbit, which has more than ten times the number of satellites than a decade ago. In 2022, the European Union released its first-ever space strategy, centered on security and defense. Several European countries, including the United Kingdom, have released their own defense strategies for outer space and have also ramped up domestic production and procurement of military satellites. Nonetheless, the majority of transatlantic countries agree that democratic values must remain the center of civil space exploration, which is reflected in the U.S.-led Artemis Accords and growing ESA membership. Canada is in a unique position, as both an Artemis signatory and special cooperative status holder within ESA. As space moves away from a domain committed primarily to science and civil cooperation and becomes a proxy for security and commercial conflicts on Earth, tensions are rising in the final frontier.

statements.eu.description: The European Union Agency for the Space Programme (EUSPA) was established in 2004 to manage the blocâ€™s space-based services. These include Galileo, which provides the most accurate positioning, navigation, and timing services worldwide; the EU Governmental Satellite Communications program, which provides secure communications services to member state governments; and Copernicus, which collects Earth observation data. In 2023, EUSPAâ€™s budget was â‚¬1.5 ($1.62) billion, all of which came from the European Commission. In 2022, the EU published its first Space Strategy for Security and Defence, which outlines the blocâ€™s counterspace capabilitiesâ€”the capacity to deny, disrupt, degrade or destroy space systemsâ€”and main vulnerabilities in space, including cyberattacks on space systems. The strategy calls for an increase in space exercises with partners and allies to improve responses to these threats. The European Space Agency (ESA), founded in 1975 as an intergovernmental organization, is the driving force behind most European space activities. Although ESA works closely with the European Union, it is not an EU agency, thereby allowing membership of non-EU countries such as Canada and the UK. In 2024, ESAâ€™s total budget was â‚¬7.88 ($8.56) billion, most of which came from member state contributions. On average, ESA members contributed â‚¬189.5 ($205.8) million in 2024.

statements.us.description: The United States established the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) in 1958, shortly after the Soviet Union launched the worldâ€™s first satellite into orbit. NASA had a budget of $27.2 billion in 2024, a 7.1% increase over the previous year. However, an April 2025 draft budget proposal for the agency reflected a 20% cut in funding. With the Department of State, NASA co-leads the Artemis Accords, a set of nonbinding principles for space exploration and activities. The accords are related to NASAâ€™s Artemis Program, which aims to put humans back on the Moon by 2027, one year before construction of the Russian and Chinese International Lunar Research Station is scheduled to begin. As of May 2023, the U.S. was the sole operator of 5165 satellites in orbit, 3950 of which belong to SpaceX, the U.S.-based spacecraft and rocket manufacturer owned by Elon Musk. The most recent overview of U.S. space policy was released in 2020. It has several objectives, including the expansion of American leadership in space by establishing a permanent human presence on the Moon. In 2019, President Donald Trump established the U.S. Space Force as an independent branch of the military. Pituffik Space Base in Greenland is the forceâ€™s northernmost installation. It plays a key role in missile defense and satellite communication capabilities, which are considered instrumental for American superiority in space. A 1962 agreement between the U.S. and Denmark established the base.
